en: Our expedition started at the bus stop in HornÃ­ VÄ›stonice, where we went uphill around the memorial church of St.Michael and the centuries -old linden and we joined the DÄ›vÃ­n nature trail, from where we went towards our first stop under Martinkou.The road to it led through the forest along the green hiking trail and was about 1.5 kilometers long.Along the way, there was a stop on the bench with a beautiful view of HornÃ­ VÄ›stonice and the NovÃ© MlÃ½ny reservoir and at the stop itself it was possible to climb uphill up to the giant stone.From there we continued 1.3 kilometers along the green hiking trail to the signpost above the gorge and from there still from the hill along the green to the foot of the hill.There was the opportunity to stop in a covered shelter with benches and tables and possibly to lunch or snap before the upcoming hike.We joined the St. James road, this time along the red hiking trail, and we started climbing the stairs up to the guard's viewpoint.The road to it was a long "only" 450 meters, but compared to the previous sections had a much more pronounced elevation.Then we continued 1.3 km along the ridge of the hill around the DÄ›vÃ­nskÃ½ crossroads, where it is possible to bypass the entire peak of the hill after several views such as the viewpoint under the transmitter and it is also possible to climb up to the transmitter itself, where in beautiful weather is appropriate view of the surrounding landscapeAnd it can also serve as a relaxing place before the final descent.From the transmitter we started to descend around the St. James road about 450 meters towards the crossroads Girl Castle Sedlo from where we walked 200 meters climbed a small elevation even to the ruins of the castle DÄ›viÄky, where we found several tables and benches and again beautiful views of PÃ¡lava.Then we just descended further along the St. James road about 1 kilometer through the forest, along the vineyards and the last stop of the statue of the angel to DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice.Several educational boards were placed along the route throughout the journey.Then we only descended further along the St. James road and then along the Archorosk of DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice - Pavlov about 1 kilometer through the forest, along the vineyards and around the penultimate stop of the statue of the angel to DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice.Here we spent the night in one of the many camps by the water and the next day we went from there to the last goal of our journey, more precisely to the Archeopark in Pavlov, which became a beautiful educational end of our route.In the end, only the final 3 -kilometer journey awaited us again after Archor Pavlov - DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice through the forest and along the beautiful PÃ¡lava vineyards again to DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice, where our expedition was successfully finished.Several educational boards were placed along the route throughout the journey, and there were countless prospects and the possibilities for sitting around the road, which relieved the overall difficulty of this route.We definitely recommend this route to people who like to go through nature and like to learn something new, and despite some steep hikes uphill, you can make a way with plenty of breaks and time to breathe and sit.In addition to good shoes and plenty of snacks and drinks, be sure to take a good mood with you and prepare for a beautiful trip on the PÃ¡lava landscape, which you will certainly not forget.

en: Beautiful nature of South Moravia.Beautifully blooming hillsides, smell of lily of the valley and lilac.The singing of birds was like a concert in Rudolfinum.A long time ago, a long time ago breathed at the orphan's castle.The view of StrÅ¾Ã­ and the rock overhang, transferred me to the time of mammoth hunters.We continued along the red hiking trail towards the Girl Castle.Every ascent up offered us an incredible view.Fields with blooming rape and hills fitted with a wine rev.Beautiful blue sky and warm rays of the sun give us the impression of a beautiful summer at the beginning of May.And for the effort we had to spend on the way up, we were rewarded by Otakarci fruit, who flew in the sky here, it was certainly a wedding.The only negative moment in Klyntnice was in refreshments at Kocour Ron.Therefore, choose another place to saturate.But again meeting with an academic painter who has a house here and opened not only the door but also his soul, he made a beautiful day of icing on the cake.

en: The PÃ¡lava Protected Landscape Area (Palava Protected Landscape Area, the abbreviation of the PÃ¡lava PLA) is a protected landscape area and a UNESCO biosphere reserve located in Moravia in the Czech Republic, on the border with Austria.The highest point is DÄ›vÃ­n with its 549 m above sea level.This unique territory was first recognized by UNESCO in 1986 and in 2003 extended by another UNESCO monument, the Lednice-Valtice cultural landscape.PÃ¡lava is dominated by PÃ¡lava limestone hills (part of the outer Western Carpathians) and contains a significant proportion of natural or slightly disturbed steppe ecosystems, which include meadow steppe, forest and thermophilic oak.In the valley of the Taiya River, forests with meadows and wetlands alternate, which include halofit vegetation.The rest of the PÃ¡lava PLA is agriculturally used, with many sustainably grown vineyards that are part of the Mikulov wine -growing sub -region.The PÃ¡lava PLA contains well -preserved monuments of historical significance, such as Paleolite in DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice, where DolnÃ­ VÄ›stonice, the ceramic figure of Venus from 29,000â€“25,000 BC.Mikulov, a town founded in the Middle Ages, lies in the southernmost part of the PÃ¡lava ÄŒKO and is located historically and architecturally important buildings, such as Mikulov Castle.

en: I visited the Å umava one -day hike (Black Lakes, the BÃ­lÃ¡ ravi area).As a natural experience, I have to say that the place was disappointing and I do not recommend a place for international tourists, at least for hiking.1) The hiking trails were mostly wide paved roads designed primarily for cyclists.The streams were drained on both sides of the road.I would prefer real hiking trails that would provide a more natural untouched experience.2) There were large areas of dead forests (I found out they were dead due to bark beetles).They were not explained in any way.I would expect some inscriptions about them.I wonder more.3) Large areas were mined and a chain saw was heard in several places.I don't think this does not belong to the national park.The felled trees seemed healthy.

en: Å umava National Park is a stunning destination that offers a unique experience for nature lovers.The park is located in the southwestern part of the Czech Republic and is home to dense forests, picturesque mountains and untouched lakes.The park is also a refuge for wildlife lovers because it is home to several rare animal species such as features, rock eagles and black storks.Whether you long for a quiet walk through the forest, hike to the top of the mountain or just relaxing on the lake, the Å umava National Park has something to offer for everyone.The Å umava National Park is not only a great destination for nature lovers, but also offers rich cultural activities.There are several historical and cultural monuments in the park, which are worth exploring.For example, the park boasts several traditional wooden churches that date from the 18th century.These churches are an excellent example of a unique architectural style of the region.In addition, visitors can explore several picturesque villages that offer a look into the traditional way of life in the Czech Republic.There are also several museums and exhibition halls in the park, which represent a rich history and culture of the region.One of the highlights of the visit to the Å umava National Park is the opportunity to taste local cuisine.The region is known for its excellent cuisine, which includes heavy meat meals, traditional soups and delicious pastries.Visitors can enjoy food in one of the many restaurants located in the park or taste local cuisine at one of the many food festivals that take place throughout the year.In addition, visitors can enjoy a glass of local beer or wine, which is renowned for its quality and taste.Overall, the Å umava National Park is a necessary destination that offers a unique combination of natural beauty, rich culture and excellent cuisine.

en: The Moravian Karst is the most extensive and most descended territory of the Czech Republic.The karst area occupies a strip of Devonian limestones north of Brno.The character of the local landscape is given by platforms with a number of sinks that separate deep canyon gowns.Most of the waters that flow from the neo -grasite part of the DrahanskÃ¡ Highlands disappear at the boundaries of limestones in submarines underground, where during long geological development created complex cave labyrinths.The northern part of the Moravian Karst is drained by a river Punk and its sources.There is a cave system of amateur cave, which with adjacent caves measures almost 35 km.In the central part of the Moravian Karst, the main cave system is a 12 km long Rudice sink - Bull Rock.In the KÅ¯lna cave, the oldest settlement of the Moravian Karst is documented by the Neanderthal man from 120,000 years ago.Remarkable are also the findings of engravings of horses and bison on horse ribs from the bakery cave.They were created by hunters and reindeer and their age is estimated to be 11,000 to 13,000 years.Caves are also the main magnet of tourism.For the public, caves of PunkÄ›vnÃ­, KateÅ™inskÃ¡, Balcarka, VÃ½pustek and Sloupsko-Å oÅ¡Å¯vskÃ© with an annual attendance of approximately 400 500 persons are made available.

en: One of the best trips.He absolutely loved the cave.If you are interested in forests and caves and visit Brno, then you have to visit the Moravian Karst.I visited in January 2022, it was great cold and snowing, but absolutely beautiful forest to see and hiking.In winter, the only cave of Punkva was made available to the public, which is the largest of the five caves found in the Moravian Karst.I read that five caves are open to the public only in summer.The Moravian Karst is located in close proximity to Blansko (from Brno to Blansko usually runs a train, but during my visit the trains did not run, so they took the bus) by bus/train from Brno to Blankso is about 30 min.ride.After you arrive in Blansko, it is about 25 minutes of taxi / by car to the Moravian Karst.There is no public transport, so having a car or taxi is a necessity if you can't walk so long.If you are a tourist and do not speak Czech, so I highly recommend booking a taxi before arrival, because in Blansko it is very difficult to find people who speak English, also when I arrived, it was Sunday and there was absolutely no taxi driver anywhere near the station.The city was very empty, I wasn't sure if it was because of Sunday, or it's normal.Uber, Bolt and other similar services don't work there either.(On the Internet you will find taxis that you can call and book them in advance) Upon arrival in the Moravian Karst, you will be able to pick up an internal train from the information office, which will stop you at the meeting to explore the cave.Be sure to come before a tour at least 45 minutes in advance.If your tour starts at 12, come at 11:15 at the latest.I arrived 25 minutes before the start of my tour and found that the train had already left, so I had to wait two hours + for the second tour.The tours are only in Czech, but even though I did not understand what the guide says, I liked the tour very much, because the cave looks absolutely amazing.Reservation in advance is a necessity.Because there are no inspections in some days/times.So don't forget to book a ticket before you plan your way.I evaluated it 4 out of five, because the tour was not well organized at all and there was absolutely no information that I had to arrive more than 30 minutes before the tour, otherwise I miss the train.It was supposed to be written on the web, instead of waiting for another tour for more than two hours.

JeskynÄ› sama o sobÄ› nemÄ›la stalagmity a stalaktity, protoÅ¾e lidÃ© se po jeskynÃ­ch rozhlÃ­Å¾eli a prochÃ¡zeli se kolem nich, ale i tak bylo docela fajn se kolem nich rozhlÃ­Å¾et.
en: Me and my family decided to come here, but we had no idea how to get there.We got into the car and put our instructions on this place, but it took us to the middle of nothing.We looked around for about an hour and tried to find it, but we found a trail that said 2 km walk, but we didn't know where to park the car.In the end we found the cave and thought we could go into it, it was just a tiny, and in fact it was not a "cave", but we still had fun (only about 5 minutes).We wanted to give up and return when we saw a small place with the table.We stopped the car and decided to go inside and it turned out that it was a place that had a real cave where people were hiding during the war.It was an educational experience and led us by a guide.It was a shame that the guide was only in Czech, so we had an English translation on paper, which was poorly read in the cave, but it was good in bunkers because there was light.The cave itself did not have stalagmites and stalactites, because people looked around and walked around the caves, but it was still quite nice to look around them.
